dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A quiet week for earnings, with all these major delays from Apple and Starbucks? That doesn't exactly scream 'market confidence' to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A quiet week for earnings, with all these major delays from Apple and Starbucks? That doesn't exactly scream 'market confidence' to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a big week for the market with a host of major companies set to report earnings as stocks pare back from near-record highs on rising concerns over the severity and economic impact of the deadly Chinese coronavirus. Its a huge week for earnings with Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon and others all reporting, even as investors grapple with the financial fallout from the deadly coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, but look—investors are actually celebrating because the coronavirus is receding. It's, uh, creating this weird financial windfall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, but look-investors are actually celebrating because the coronavirus is receding. It's, uh, creating this weird financial windfall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hopes that the virus would be contained were squashed over the weekend, says Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial. Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A windfall? Even with companies like Tesla still expecting losses around, what was it, $1.95 per share?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A windfall? Even with companies like Tesla still expecting losses around, what was it, one point nine five dollars per share?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but Amazon's projected to hit $80 billion in sales! And the indexes are way up—S&P 500 gained 1.6% Monday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Amazon's projected to hit eighty dollars billion in sales! And the indexes are way up-S&P five hundred gained one point six percent Monday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but that feels short-sighted. Didn't SARS back in 2003 show a similar pattern before a crash? Sarah Zaccarelli pointed that out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but that feels short-sighted. Didn't S A R S back in two thousand three show a similar pattern before a crash? Sarah Zaccarelli pointed that out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: She did, but Peter Detrick says investors are taking a 'buy first, ask questions later' approach right now. The sentiment's just really positive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: She did, but Peter Detrick says investors are taking a 'buy first, ask questions later' approach right now. The sentiment's just really positive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Positive? With more than fifty cities still on lockdown and consumer demand taking a hit? That seems contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Positive? With more than fifty cities still on lockdown and consumer demand taking a hit? That seems contradictory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown), and U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it's counterintuitive, but Ben Crisafulli called it an 'added tailwind' for market stability. And crude oil hit a six-month high!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it's counterintuitive, but Ben Crisafulli called it an 'added tailwind' for market stability. And crude oil hit a six-month high!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. I just worry this optimism might be premature. Historically, outbreaks like this have been selling opportunities, not buying frenzies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. I just worry this optimism might be premature. Historically, outbreaks like this have been selling opportunities, not buying frenzies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For the long term, maybe, but short-term? Stocks are reacting to the vaccine progress and China's containment success. It's driving things up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For the long term, maybe, but short-term? Stocks are reacting to the vaccine progress and China's containment success. It's driving things up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone, but Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I'll believe it when I see sustained growth. For now, it feels like a bubble waiting to pop.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I'll believe it when I see sustained growth. For now, it feels like a bubble waiting to pop.

HostA: Okay, but that feels short-sighted. Didn't SARS back in 2003 show a similar pattern before a crash? Sarah Zaccarelli pointed that out.

HostB: I know, it's counterintuitive, but Ben Crisafulli called it an 'added tailwind' for market stability. And crude oil hit a six-month high!
HostA: Hmm. I just worry this optimism might be premature. Historically, outbreaks like this have been selling opportunities, not buying frenzies.

HostA: I'll believe it when I see sustained growth. For now, it feels like a bubble waiting to pop.
